sentence: Without any notable Home Depot Inc. (NYSE: HD ) news on the wires, call volume in the August expiration month received a boost from an investor who bet on limited upside.
By 2:30 p.m. EST, more than 16,000 of the August 34 calls have hit the tape with the stock down 55 cents to $34.
The bulk of the options traded at 10:41 a.m. EST, when a block of more than 10,000 contracts traded for $1.90 apiece.
This hefty volume compares to current open interest of 18,953 contracts at this at-the-money strike.
So it is not conclusive if this is a new position, or if the investor is selling to close the options.
But the selling is not helping the stock to rally.
The August 34 calls have thus far declined 28 cents on the day, computing to an implied volatility of 29 compared to a realized volatility of 23 for the past 3 months.
Call-selling activity such as this does not mean investors should run out and sell their HD shares.
However, it is noteworthy that this investor is choosing to sell the August series.
Based on recent history, it is likely that HD will report their quarterly results just prior to August expiration.
So if this trade were motivated by a bet that implied volatility might decline, the investor is discounting the possibility of an outsized move due to earnings.
Home Depot just reported results back on May 18.
By selling these calls, this trade could be indicating that they view the next three months as unlikely to result in much movement from HD shares.
